dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, have you seen what's happening with Relativity Space? I mean, uh, their founders, Tim Ellis and Jordan Noone, they're really pushing the boundaries with their Terran 2 rocket.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, have you seen what's happening with Relativity Space? I mean, uh, their founders, Tim Ellis and Jordan Noone, they're really pushing the boundaries with their Terran two rocket.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Space Relativity founders Tim Ellis and Jordan Noone examine the second stage of their Terran 1 rocket, which was entirely 3D-printed

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah! The one that's, like, completely 3D-printed? That just blows my mind, honestly. A whole rocket?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah! The one that's, like, completely 3D-printed? That just blows my mind, honestly. A whole rocket?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company is 3D-printing its rockets, from the engine to the structure, and has recently seen success in building first and second stages of its Terran 1 design.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! They just examined the third stage of it, and it's all 3D-printed. And get this: they just secured a massive capital raise.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! They just examined the third stage of it, and it's all 3D-printed. And get this: they just secured a massive capital raise.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Space Relativity founders Tim Ellis and Jordan Noone examine the second stage of their Terran 1 rocket, which was entirely 3D-printed

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Oh, I saw that! Wasn't Warren Buffett, like, their first investor? And Elon Musk's fund, uh, led this new round?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, I saw that! Wasn't Warren Buffett, like, their first investor? And Elon Musk's fund, uh, led this new round?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Los Angeles-based startup has a lot of believers, including billionaire Mark Cuban, the companys first investor and also a participant in the current round, which was led by Noah Knauf at Bond fund and Tribe Capital.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yep, you got it. Buffett was in early, and SpaceX's fund and Tribe Capital led this $150 million round, bringing them to $190 million total. Ellis says they're "fully funded to launch" now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yep, you got it. Buffett was in early, and SpaceX's fund and Tribe Capital led this one hundred fifty million dollar round, bringing them to one hundred ninety million dollars total. Ellis says they're fully funded to launch now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The $140 million fundraise brings the total amount of investment in the company to $185 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, they're launching from Vandenberg. But, I mean, the space market is pretty crowded, right? Like, a hundred other startups are trying to do small rockets.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, they're launching from Vandenberg. But, I mean, the space market is pretty crowded, right? Like, a hundred other startups are trying to do small rockets.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its rocket will launch from Cape Canaveral.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It is, completely. But here's where Relativity thinks they have the edge, you know? It's all about that 3D-printing process. From the engine to the structure, everything.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is, completely. But here's where Relativity thinks they have the edge, you know? It's all about that 3D-printing process. From the engine to the structure, everything.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Relativitys Ellis believes that its competitive advantage lies in its manufacturing process. The company is 3D-printing its rockets, from the engine to the structure...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So that's their secret sauce? Like, what does that actually *do* for them, though? Besides sounding cool?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So that's their secret sauce? Like, what does that actually do for them, though? Besides sounding cool?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they've built these huge 3D-printers, they call them 'Starforge.' And once the factory's built and scaled, Ellis says it's a "significantly more automated process." They can produce and iterate rockets super quickly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they've built these huge 3D-printers, they call them Starforge. And once the factory's built and scaled, Ellis says it's a significantly more automated process. They can produce and iterate rockets super quickly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To that end, the company has built four large 3D-printers, which it calls Stargate, at its manufacturing facility.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, automation. That makes sense. So, uh, do they actually have customers lined up yet? Or is this all still, like, theoretical?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, automation. That makes sense. So, uh, do they actually have customers lined up yet? Or is this all still, like, theoretical?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, not at all! They've already signed deals. Vodafone for internet satellites, LG Electronics, and even Spaceflight, which will launch several of *their* customers' satellites. Launches are $15 million a pop, too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not at all! They've already signed deals. Vodafone for internet satellites, L G Electronics, and even Spaceflight, which will launch several of their customers' satellites. Launches are fifteen million dollars a pop, too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company has signed deals with Canadian communications company Telesat to deliver internet satellites to orbit, with Thai company mu Space, and with Spaceflight... Launches cost $10 million, in the ballpark of current satellite launches.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's pretty competitive! I mean, I guess it shows that this 3D-printing thing isn't just a gimmick then.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's pretty competitive! I mean, I guess it shows that this 3D-printing thing isn't just a gimmick then.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And Ellis isn't even stopping at Earth's orbit. Part of their long-term vision, he says, is to one day be 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure on the moon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And Ellis isn't even stopping at Earth's orbit. Part of their long-term vision, he says, is to one day be 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure on the moon.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Part of our long-term vision is one day 3D-printing rockets and infrastructure on Mars, he says.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: On the *moon*?! That's, like, next level. Imagine that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: On the moon?! That's, like, next level. Imagine that.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: I know, right? It's pretty wild to think about, but hey, if anyone can pull it off, maybe it's the guys who are 3D-printing whole rockets here on Earth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know, right? It's pretty wild to think about, but hey, if anyone can pull it off, maybe it's the guys who are 3D-printing whole rockets here on Earth.
